content: The pay for congressional staff is determined by the chair and ranking Member in Senate committees, including job titles, pay rates, and resources. The pay for congressional staff is determined by the chair and ranking Member in Senate committees, including job titles, pay rates, and resources. Congressional pay data may be of interest for assessing costs, setting pay levels, and comparing with other federal government systems. Publicly available sources do not provide aggregated congressional staff pay data, but data in this report is based on official Senate reports, published semiannually. The pay data for Senate committee staff positions is based on official Senate reports published semiannually by the Secretary of the Senate. The report provides pay information for 13 staff position titles and allows for observations about staff compensation over time. This report provides pay data for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees since FY2001. Position titles were identified through a two-step process, with 25 titles assessed for staff employment across 20 Senate committees. In FY2014, 277 Senate committee staff positions were filled by only one staff member, with 25 titles assessed for employment across 20 committees. Twelve positions used by six or fewer panels were excluded, and pay data was collected for the remaining 13 positions. Annual pay data needed to be available from at least five committees for each position to be included. Annual pay data for Senate committee staff positions must be available from at least five committees to be included. Data is collected for no more than two staff per committee with the same job title. Staff must hold the position for the entire fiscal year and not receive pay from any other congressional employing authority. Tabulated payments may differ from stated salaries due to inclusion of overtime, bonuses, or other factors. The LegiStorm data tabulates every recorded payment for congressional staff for the fiscal year, including overtime, bonuses, and other payments in addition to base salary. Pay data for House committee staff is available in CRS Report R44322, while data for Senate and House personal office staff is available in CRS Report R44324. Pay Levels for Selected Positions in House Committees, 2001-2014 are available in CRS Report R44323. Data may not represent all jobs due to the large number of positions held by one Senate employee. Some challenges may affect the interpretation of findings on Senate committee staff positions. Data collected may not represent all jobs due to the large number of positions held by one employee. The assignment of staff titles could impact the data's representativeness. Two broad categories of positions were identified, with pay information likely to be highly representative for positions usually held by one staff member per committee. Two broad categories of Senate committee staff positions were identified based on the data collected. The first category consists of positions usually held by one staff member per committee, with pay information likely to be highly representative. The second category includes positions where committees might hire two or more staff members, with pay data collected for a sample of staff in those positions. The data collected for Senate committee staff positions may not be fully representative as it is based on a sample of staff rather than complete data. Pay information does not consider factors such as education, work experience, or job duties. Assumptions are made that staff with the same title have similar tasks, but differences may exist. Congressional employing authorities have wide discretion in determining pay. The Senate Handbook acknowledges that individuals with the same job title in Congress may have vastly different duties, leading to potential differences in compensation. Congressional employing authorities have wide discretion in setting terms of employment, which could impact pay levels. Tables in this section provide background information on Senate pay practices. The Senate Handbook acknowledges the variability in duties and compensation among individuals with the same job title in Congress. Tables in this section provide detailed data on Senate pay practices, including maximum payable rates for Senate committee staff since 2001 in both nominal and constant 2016 dollars. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay for various staff positions in Washington, DC, changed significantly, with some positions experiencing increases while others saw declines in pay. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay for staff positions in Washington, DC, varied significantly, with some positions experiencing pay increases while others saw declines. The changes ranged from a 16.93% increase for professional staff members to a -16.48% decrease for staff assistants. Comparatively, Members of Congress saw a -5.10% change in pay, and General Schedule, DC, saw a -3.19% change during the same period. From FY2006 to FY2015, median pay changes ranged from a 22.01% increase for senior counsels to a -26.72% decrease for staff assistants, with four positions seeing pay increases and four seeing declines. Between FY2001 and FY2015, median pay changes for staff positions in Washington, DC varied significantly. Pay increases ranged from 30.88% for systems administrators to -26.67% for staff assistants. Five out of seven positions saw pay increases during this period. Comparatively, Members of Congress had a -10.41% change in pay and General Schedule, DC, had a -0.13% change from 2006 to 2015.
